query: SELECT DISTINCT observations.id FROM `observations` ORDER BY observations.id ASC

results.notes:
Stipe yellowish with red streaks and (darkened) pruina. Base with red/yellow fuzz and longer white hairs. Apex yellow.

Stipe context yellow with lower 25% vivid cherry red. Staining blue, but at first, not completely and not strongly. Red basal area becoming dark blue after a few minutes.

Cap brownish with darker blotches. Cap context pale yellow staining blue.

Pore surface orange, margin yellow. Bruising black.

Ammonia: dark brown on cap, yellow on context.
KOH: mahogany on cap, rusty orange on context.

In a field under a small spruce (I think blue spruce). Spruce at edge of mixed woods with hemlock, birch, maple.

I specifically wanted to find at least one of these Vermont subvelutipes types with the vivid red context in the stipe base. Found this one as I was exiting the woods on my last foray into the woods where I was staying. This appears to be a post-mature specimen with darkened surface features and less prominent blue staining of context; but in otherwise excellent condition. I had my dehydrator with me, and manged to get the material fairly well-dried before driving home. Finished drying at home.

In the past, I considered this VT type to be different than subvelutipes, and have applied the name luridiformis, obs 50052.

results.notes: Attached to woody debris in mainly hardwood forest.

results.notes:
The collection/photo was taken on the Siltcoos Lake Trail near Florence, Oregon.

Displayed at Cascade Mycological Society mushroom festival. Identifiers included Bitty Roy, Steve Trudell, Debbie Viess, Freeman Rowe, Erin Page Blanchard, Joe Spivak and others from CMS.

Originally lumped in with a group of Pycnoporellus alboluteus.
results.location_name: Siltcoos Lake Trail #1333, Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area, Siuslaw National Forest, Douglas Co. and Lane Co., Oregon, USA

results.notes:
I have never seen a single fungi so prevalent (by weight) in one area at one time as this. It was growing in at least ten places in groups of three-five and each one weighed over a pound.

I’d like to note it seems like R. compacta, but it isn’t bruising brown and I didn’t notice a fishy smell (however my sense of smell is bad so I don’t trust it).
results.location_name: Hickory Run State Park, Carbon Co., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes: Cap measuring 11 cm. Stalk (above bulb) about 11 cm. The warts on the cap as described by Kuo – randomly distributed with ones smaller and denser near the margin. Skirt-like ring. Large , prominent basal bulb. The most perfect and fresh Amanita I have ever seen. Very striking. Found singly in oak/hickory woods.

results.notes:
Cap tan, 11 cm. stipe 7 cm. Spore color olive/brown. In soil in oak/hickory woods. Stipe whitish in color. Pores yellow. Appears to be an older specimen.
Cap somewhat odd-shaped, not exactly circular. Specimen butted next to a large piece of decaying wood. When sliced, blue bruising occurred. Inside of stipe bright red. Do not know if that was a result of slicing or whether it was red inside prior. Since the outer part of the stipe showed red at the apex, I am guessing it was red inside prior to slicing. Of course, this may be totally incorrect.

results.notes:
Gymnopilus P. Karst.
This is a copy of 248718.
Cap: 5-9 cm, convex up to broadly convex, then flat up to sunken with wavy margins when old, usually with indistinct knob; orange-yellow or yellow-orange with light margins, sometimes lemon-yellow; surface smooth, minor fine velvety.
Gills: attached and slightly descending stalk, close, narrow with short and very short intermediate gills, color light yellow and light cream up to bright yellow or orange yellow, then brownish-orange when old.
Stalk: 6-12cm long, 0.8-1.6cm thick, often hairy, fibrous when old, irregular colored dull orange-yellow, brownish dirty yellow or orange-brown when old (top is lighter and more yellow).
Edibility: edible after boiling.
Habitat: common kind, small group, minor big clusters along pine roots or on partially rotten pine wood in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
July – September.

Kaibab National Forest, Coconino Co., Arizona, USA

results.notes:
Found in grass and moss between oaks by the Deer Browse shelters. It’s been quite dry and all the mushrooms we found (many bulbous-type bicolors too) were less “hefty” than usual. The caps did not become marshmallowy, but I believe there was definitely some missing water weight. The fb’s also seem to be more bug-infested than is usual for this location.

Pores range in color from maroon/brown (youngest specimens) to orange/brown (adults) to yellow/brown (older specimens). All pores stain black, not blue.

Stipes are yellow (BUT NOTE: On the far side of the field we found some that could be this species, but are most likely a yellow-pored species that dried toward brown rather than this maroon-pored species drying toward yellow. They had a good amount of dried-out pink in the stipe). No reticulation or other features of note.

Context yellow. The cap flesh blues with moderate speed and then fades. The stipe flesh did not stain at all. Smell normal. Taste is SWEET! (Kate confirms this on a blind double-check). Texture is firm but less heavy than I’m used to, and a bit brittle. Mycelium white.

The split specimen in the first picture was used for chemical tests. All of the results were slow. The biggest surprises were (a) ammonia had different reaction on the cap skin and the stem skin, and (b) the cap flesh was noticeably more reactive than the stem flesh:

Ammonia on Cap Skin: Orange.
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: Yellow – NOT orange.
Ammonia on Pores: Orange, but very slow.
Ammonia on Cap Context: No reaction, but eliminated the staining in a wide area.
Ammonia on Stipe Context:No reaction. There was no staining to be eliminated.

KOH on Cap Skin: Orange (a deeper shade than for ammonia)
KOH on Stipe Skin: Orange
KOH on Pores: Orange.
KOH on Cap Context: Orange.
KOH on Stipe Context: No reaction, or maybe a faint orange.

FeCl3 on Cap Skin: Olive yellow/green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Skin: Olive yellow/green.
FeCl3 on Pores: Olive/black.
FeCl3 on Cap Context: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Context: Olive green.

Growing on dead hardwood, species uncertain. Largest cap 50 mm wide. Caps slick on a damp day, but not viscid. White tomentum present near point of attachment; caps otherwise glabrous and not striate. Spore print brown. No distinctive odor.

originally thought to be Gloeoporus taxicola until told on FB that this was a strictly poroid taxon, now reconsidering that name on account of Swiss 2’s explicit description of the hymenium as merulioid. micro also agrees pretty well.

spores tiny (~3-5×1-2μm), difficult to observe clearly, cylindrical-bacilliform to slightly (bean) to strongly (macaroni) curved, straighter ones appearing to have one rounded/slightly inflated and one pointed end; basidia not projecting beyond hymenium, bisterigmate (?); cystidia absent, or, if present, then strongly resembling basidioles, some with slightly enlarged apices, others more or less even with undifferentiated apices, others slightly enlarged at the center and tapering to a rounded apex; clamp connections absent

Substrate: on bark of recently fallen, very firm Ponderosa Pine

Habitat: Pinyon-Juniper Rocky Mountain Forest

Ecoregion: transition zone between Colorado Rockies Forests (NA0511) and Colorado Plateau shrublands (NA1304)

Collectors: D. Newman & P. Kaishian

results.notes:
If you have never seen an intermediate/younger form of this mushroom growing in the NJ Pine Barrens, you would never guess this clunky, ugly and very smelly bolete is T. balloui and probably drive yourself crazy trying to ID it. Fortunately, I have — see obs 74480 from 5 years ago — but neither that nor the normal/pretty form (obs 74479) is what we usually find. For another example of this monstrosity, see obs 245958.
The dramatically tapered down to a point stipes and caespitose growth are a very common occurrence. The exposed context is bruising pinkish-brown. The taste is immediately bitter. The odor is reminiscent of a musty cellar. The observed chemical tests are consistent with those reported in NAB for this species:
KOH = amber brown changing to chocolate brown and fading back to medium brown on pileipellis; yellow on cap context
FeSO4 = blue changing to deep violet blue on pileipellis; inky blue on cap context.

results.notes:
Gills seem too developed for secotioid development.

If I understand him correctly this specimen is probably A. didymus that has acquired genes from an unknown Agaricus sp. that is causing it to start the process of becoming secotioid. results.notes:
Two collections (photos A and B). A from mixed woods including oak. B from oak-dominated hardwood area.

Blue bruising on stipes and pores. Slow staining variable on cut cap context.

KOH applied to red surface areas (cap, stipe) dark bluish-green flash quickly resolving to orange and developing a metallic (shiny) luster. Other bicolors I have tested (different location in NE PA) have also exhibited the green-flash-to-orange reaction on red surface areas, particularly the cap. Areas without red pigment do not exhibit the KOH green flash but do exhibit the KOH shiny orange reaction.

Smash mount of material from tube layer appeared to yield both immature and mature spores. Lengths ranged from 8 to 13 microns.

Material from collection B preserved.

results.notes:
This tripartite/quadripartite system seems to be found wherever certain Fomes/Fomitopsis species grow and, eventually, rot. I have now seen this or something like it in the PNW, upstate New York and the Sierras. It involves said polypore substrate, Hypocrea (aff.?) pulvinata, and one or more uniperitheciate sordariomycetes with long, slender ostiolar necks. John Plischke had species level IDs for what he believed to be two species co-occurring on this material — Melanospora lagenaria and Ophiostoma polyporicola — at least one of which may be present in this observation as well. The Melanospora is supposed to have paler, oranger necks, as opposed to the darker Ophiostoma. If both are present in this specimen, I can’t tell them apart. Maybe this is neither! Perhaps John will weigh in himself at some point.

Joshua Birkebak (Shua) was given a piece to culture before we had any names beyond guesses at family for the tiny ascos. Awaiting word back on what he finds.

Compare with Observation 33996, Observation 220002 and Observation 246899

results.notes:
Description:

Pileus:
57 mm diameter, olivaceous greybrown to darker olivaceous brown with reddish hues on umbo, dark in center, paler outer half, margin sulcate upto 55% of the cap, remarkable umbo.

Lamellae:
Fairly wide apart, lamellulae of irregular length, creamy white, grey flocculose margins, fairly narrow, adnexed and slightly decurrent at the apex.

Stipe:
130×5-7 mm, 13 mm at broadest point of volva, very slender (gracile), tapering towards the pileus, at pileal attachment just a bit wider, from 20 mm under the pileus to 20 mm above volva covered with fine fibrils that are concolourous with the cap.

Volva:
34×13 mm, white (especially on the uppper half), brunnescent after holding it while carrying it home (I didn’t expect finding it to be honest, hence I had no basket), sheathing, limbate, submembraneous.

Context:
White, very thin in the cap, brownish cortex in the lower half of the stipe, hollow, but stuffed with cottony tissue. No particular odour or flavor.

Habitat:
Very moist probably more or less acidic soil with thick humus layer, thick moss layer, associated with either Betula or Picea (see photos for exact species, I’m not sure which they are).

Notes:
As I didn’t had the time nor the tools to properly dry the specimen, this collection constists of thin slices pressed between the pages of my notebook (as often done with plant specimens). So alas they are not of the usual quality. For microscopy this will not be a real problem, as I have experienced with other similar collections I have that are a couple of years old.
However, I did manage to air dry a small piece of cap with hymenium for molecular analysis. This specimen is contained in a sterile test tube. I will send this tube to you, Rod!
I found this one, wasn’t able to see if it was edible or not.
Another specimen, did not recognize.
The fungus is on apple trees.
No idea in the type of fungus, these pictures I got them from apple trees.

Interestingly this specimen was growing from Betula roots, rather than its usual coniferous host… Anyone knows whether this is common for this species, or if there is a similar species for broadleaf trees?

results.notes:
A single basidiocarp growing at an awkward angle in moss from the base of a young red maple in a bog off Prince Street. The bulb is not abrupt, and doesn’t have clefts, so that A. brunnescens and allies can be eliminated.
The immediate habitat is of red maple, Atlantic white cedar and black gum. A few mature pitch pines are 15 yards away, but may still be the host tree. Despite the recent rains, the bog was unusually dry.
The specimen was not preserved owing to the poor shape of the hymenophore.

results.notes: A solitary, immature specimen fruiting in soil in Oak-Hickory woods. Cap (as measured across the top): 5 cm., dry with dark appressed fibers. I tweezed away the partial veil to reveal white gills which changed to a pinky-gray overnight and finally to brown as spores were released on third day. Stipe: 7.7 cm. X 7 mm., curved and with abruptly swollen base. Yellow staining on stipe and cap margin, and on flesh when sliced. Very strong odor of anise oil (noticeable even when cap was laid on the table next to where I was sitting). KOH yellow on cap. Brown spore print.

results.notes: Growing on pine.

These things were covered by duff and incredibly small. Cap 2 mm; no pine needles in sight.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 146003214 on January 6, 2023.

> I found these at the NJMA foray, growing in leaf litter and tenuous soil around scattered boulders in mixed deciduous woods with red and white oak, chestnut oak, maple and other hardwoods.
Description: The partially expanded caps are 7-8 cm wide and 1.5-2.0 cm thick in the center. The caps’ original color is rosy-red (i.e., more bicolor-like) at the time of collection in the woods, but the pictures taken ~2.5 hrs post collection show a different hue (notice the “dimples” are still purple-red to rose-red); hours later, the color was observed as tannish-pink over the disc and still rose-red toward the periphery. The pore surface is dingy lemon yellow, bluing when injured; the bluing gradually dissipates to grayish brown, finally resolving medium brown. The pores are clogged in the young fb, as visualize with a lens, and are variably-sized and round in the older fb, 3-4 pores per mm. The tube layer is 3-4 mm thick at the widest section, bluing when cut. The stipes are 8-9 cm long, 1.5-1.7 cm wide at the apex and 1.8-2.3 cm wide at the base, curved and twisted, and with a very uneven and convoluted surface topology. The stipe surface color is ranging from medium scarlet red in the bottom half, transitioning to orangish-red and mixed with yellow-brown hues the upper half, with a very narrow yellow band at the juncture with the pore surface. The younger fb is unevenly reticulate over the upper 1-1.5 cm on one side of the stipe and is smooth on the other side; the older fb is delicately reticulate just at the apex.
The context is very firm, especially in the stipe, whitish to very pale yellow in the cap, light to medium lemon yellow in the stipe, gradually bluing in the cap above the tubes (in the smaller fb), with just a trace of bluing in the older one (see pix).
Taste is mild and not distinct. The odor is reminiscent of chicken bouillon to my nose; this was confirmed by two other individuals at the foray.
Macrochemical tests: KOH = amber yellow-brown at first, then rusty orange-brown on cap surface; pale orange on cap context. NH3 = at first pale rusty orange, resolving to mustard yellow with a diffuse green zone around the yellow on the cap surface; erasing the bluing but otherwise negative to yellowish on the cap flesh. FeSO4 = grayish olive green on cap surface; negative to pale slate on cap context.
The gestalt morphology and the chicken bouillon odor are consistent with the description of Boletus pallidoroseus.
DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion (last update/edit 12-Nov-17):
> Partial contiguous nrITS and nrLSU sequences were obtained for this material. Both sequences suffered from a non-specificity issue affecting a portion of the read in the middle. More specifically, the annotated report reads: “The nrITS sequence becomes non-specific early in the ITS1 region and the overall trace appears too long to try to join a haplotype contig from the other end. The nrLSU trace is missing about 1/3 of the 5’ end because there is a non-specific region between primers LR22 and LR3.” Nevertheless, both sequences are still useful, as the nrITS contiguous fragment is 541 nucleotides long and the nrLSU contiguous fragment is 920 nucleotides long.
> A GenBank BLAST search of the nrITS fragment did not return an matching or meaningful hits. There are no B. pallidoroseus ITS sequences in Genbank. Lack of hits eliminates the possibility of this being B. bicolor, for GB sequences of that taxon do exist (whether they are correctly identified remains to be seen).
> As expected, a GenBank BLASTn search of the “full-length” nrLSU fragment did not return any matching or meaningful hits. However, a search of the first 445 characters (through the LR5 region) gave the following hit profile:
1) Boletus bicolor voucher TH6933 (#AY612800) = 100% match. This is almost certainly a misidentification (see discussion in obs 210760)
2) Boletus pallidoroseus voucher snHor01 (#KF030305) = 99.8% match
3) Lanmaoa carminipes voucher MB06-001 (#JQ327001) = 99.5% match
4) Lanmaoa asiatica HKAS54094 (KF112353) = 99.0% match
5) Lanmaoa asiatica HKAS63592 (KM605142) = 99.0% match
6) Lanmaoa asiatica HKAS54095 (KM605141) = 98.8% match
7) Lanmaoa angustispora HKAS74765 (KF112322) = 97.8% match
8)-10) Three more Lanmaoa vouchers with ~98% similarity
Furthermore, alignment of the “full-length” nrLSU fragment of 247881 with the corresponding 920 bp region of my benchmark B. pallidoroseus voucher, obs 210760, shows them to be 100% identical.
> A clean and contiguous TEF-1-α sequence of 610 bps was also obtained from this collection. There are 5 ambiguous characters: one “R” and four “Y”. Alignment of this sequence with that of obs 210760 shows them to differ only in the 4 ambiguous characters (the two traces share one of the "Y"’s). Thus the similarity of the two sequences can be as low as 99.3% and as high as 100%. For a TEF-1 BLASTn search profile, see the discussion in 210760.
> Based on the morphological and molecular profile of this collection, the best diagnosis at this time is Boletus pallidoroseus/Lanmaoa pallidorosea.

results.location_name: Umstead State Park, Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

results.notes:
Found in mixed woods,
Cap 4 cm in diameter
Stipe 8 cm long 1cm wide nearly equal , pinched at the base. Cream color or slightly yellow, stains on handling to pinkish brown and turn to black within a couple minute. It has long raised ridges. At the apex stained green when it broke of the cap.
Cap color light brown to yellowish with some peachy undertone. On handling stains brownish to black. Taste mild and pleasant. Odor not distinctive.
Pore surface cream to light cinnamon stains greenish to pinkish to brown and later almost black
I did not have chemicals with me at the time of collection.
Buy the next day all staining where black and dark brown.
Unfortunately someone else find it and I could not locate hem or her for more info.
more of these in nearly the same location as before at trail entrance.
